articles.headline: Madoff Investor Said to Have Drowned
articles.snippet: Jeffry M. Picower, who reaped billions in Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme, drowned after suffering a “massive heart attack,” according to a family lawyer.
articles.abstract: Jeffry M. Picower, who reaped billions in Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme, drowned after suffering a “massive heart attack,” according to a family lawyer.
articles.lead_paragraph: An autopsy shows that Jeffry M. Picower, a prominent philanthropist accused of reaping about $7 billion in profit from Bernard L. Madoff’s vast Ponzi scheme, drowned on Sunday after having a heart attack.

articles.headline: Off-Course Pilots Cite Computer Distraction
articles.snippet: Two pilots who flew past the Minneapolis-St. Paul airport told investigators that they were distracted by a discussion of a new crew-scheduling system.
articles.abstract: Two pilots who flew past the Minneapolis-St. Paul airport told investigators that they were distracted by a discussion of a new crew-scheduling system.
articles.lead_paragraph: Any employee at a company that has gone through a merger knows how distracting it can be when the new owner imposes new rules. That distraction, not a nap, was what two Northwest Airlines pilots say caused them to fly far beyond the Minneapolis airport last week, federal investigators reported Monday.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Matthew L. Wald

articles.headline: For Delphi Pensioners, the Union Label Helps
articles.snippet: A General Motors deal with the government that ensures Delphi’s union workers have their pension benefits restored does not cover nonunion workers.
articles.abstract: A General Motors deal with the government that ensures Delphi’s union workers have their pension benefits restored does not cover nonunion workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WARREN, Ohio  Bruce Gump and his neighbors feared for their retirement checks when the federal government took over the pension plans at Delphi, the big auto parts maker where they once worked.

articles.headline: CNN Last in TV News on Cable
articles.snippet: The pioneer in the all-news cable TV format loses viewers’ interest in the political scrum between Fox on the right and MSNBC on the left.
articles.abstract: The pioneer in the all-news cable TV format loses viewers’ interest in the political scrum between Fox on the right and MSNBC on the left.
articles.lead_paragraph: CNN, which created the all-news cable network almost 30 years ago, hit a new competitive low with its prime-time programs in October, with three of its four programs between 7 and 11 p.m. finishing fourth and last among the cable news networks.

articles.headline: Ex-A.I.G. Chief Is Back, Luring Talent From Rescued Firm
articles.snippet: Maurice R. Greenberg’s new company may soon start to siphon off business from A.I.G., and, therefore, its means to repay its debt to the government.
articles.abstract: Maurice R. Greenberg’s new company may soon start to siphon off business from A.I.G., and, therefore, its means to repay its debt to the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: Maurice R. Greenberg, who built the American International Group into an insurance behemoth with an impenetrable maze of on- and offshore companies, is at it again.

articles.headline: Post-Bailout Blues as Europe Orders ING Group to Sell 2 Units
articles.snippet: Governments around the world are wrestling with just how much to rein in the financial behemoths that contributed to the global banking crisis.
articles.abstract: Governments around the world are wrestling with just how much to rein in the financial behemoths that contributed to the global banking crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: A year ago, governments around the world scrambled to pull their biggest banks from the brink of collapse. Now, policy makers are wrestling with just how much to rein in the financial behemoths that contributed to the crisis.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and David Jolly

articles.headline: German Limits on War Face Afghan Reality
articles.snippet: The German Army has been engaged in fighting in Afghanistan on a scale not seen since World War II, just as the war effort grows unpopular at home.
articles.abstract: The German Army has been engaged in fighting in Afghanistan on a scale not seen since World War II, just as the war effort grows unpopular at home.
articles.lead_paragraph: KUNDUZ, Afghanistan  Forced to confront the rising insurgency in once peaceful northern Afghanistan, the German Army is engaged in sustained and bloody ground combat for the first time since World War II.

articles.headline: For Runaways, Sex Buys Survival
articles.snippet: Nearly a third of the children who flee home engage in sex for food, drugs or a place to stay, studies have found.
articles.abstract: Nearly a third of the children who flee home engage in sex for food, drugs or a place to stay, studies have found.
articles.lead_paragraph: ASHLAND, Ore.  She ran away from her group home in Medford, Ore., and spent weeks sleeping in parks and under bridges. Finally, Nicole Clark, 14 years old, grew so desperate that she accepted a young man’s offer of a place to stay. The price would come later.

articles.headline: Fears of a New Chill in Home Sales
articles.snippet: The August data from a home price index suggested that a housing recovery is taking hold.
articles.abstract: The August data from a home price index suggested that a housing recovery is taking hold.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as new figures show house prices have risen for three consecutive months, concerns are growing that the real estate market will be severely tested this winter.
